metadata.case_name: State of Uttar Pradesh v. Mohammad Naim

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge of Hardoi tried Zafar Ali Khan and three others on charges under ss. 452 and 307 read with s. 34, Indian Penal Code.

First information report lodged at Shahabad police station purporting to be at 3.30 A.M. by Farasat Ali Khan on night between 7th and 8th November, 1958. Investigated by Mohammad Naim, Station Officer.
Trial court convicted accused but found FIR more probably lodged at 7 or 8 A.M. rather than 3.30 A.M.
Appeal to Allahabad High Court Lucknow Bench heard by Mulla J., who acquitted accused, finding Mohammad Naim dressed up unbelievable case, destroying evidentiary value of prosecution witnesses.
Mulla J. observed FIR time was fictitious fabrication, directed notice to Mohammad Naim why complaint under s.195 IPC should not be instituted.
Mohammad Naim appeared, apologized; Mulla J. accepted apology hesitatingly in Cr. Misc. Case No. 348/1961, made observations criticizing police force.
State of UP applied under s.561A CrPC to expunge specific observations grouped as (a), (b), (c).

Mulla J. dismissed application, holding State had no locus standi, observations required clarification to UP police only, some expungeable if aggrieved party approached, others based on personal knowledge.
State sought certificate under Art.134(1)(c) Constitution, denied, then special leave under Art.136 granted by SC on April 12, 1962.

legal_issues.text: Whether the State of Uttar Pradesh had locus standi to make application under s.561A CrPC
Whether High Court has inherent power under s.561A CrPC to expunge remarks made by itself or lower court to prevent abuse of process or secure ends of justice
Whether the present case is exceptional requiring exercise of inherent jurisdiction to expunge the observations

petitioner_arguments.text: Observations over entire police force bring it into contempt, lower prestige, interfere with administration, injure State security; not necessary, separable, no evidence.

respondent_arguments.text: State not aggrieved party, no locus standi; State represents executive and judiciary, anomalous; observations based on personal knowledge, not overstated except clarification needed.

court_reasoning.text: State Government has locus standi under s.561A as executive power vests in Governor, police is its department, State is juristic person recognized in CrPC provisions like s.417.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No anomaly in State invoking inherent jurisdiction when aggrieved.

court_reasoning.text: High Court has inherent power under s.561A to expunge remarks by itself or lower court in exceptional cases to secure ends of justice; jurisdiction exceptional.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Confirms view of High Courts other than Bombay HC.

court_reasoning.text: Remarks sweeping generalizations against entire police force unwarranted, not based on evidence, not necessary for decision; betray lack of judicial restraint; exceptional case for expungement.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Judges must exercise restraint; personal knowledge insufficient for such broad condemnations.

holdings.text: State Government has locus standi to invoke s.561A CrPC when aggrieved by remarks against its departments.
High Court has inherent power under s.561A to expunge remarks in exceptional cases.
Remarks (a), (b), (c) should be expunged as unwarranted and unnecessary.

precedents_cited.relevance: s.561A preserves inherent powers of High Court.
HC can expunge remarks in exceptional cases.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of U.P. v. J.N. Bagga
precedents_cited.citation: judgment in Cr. A. 122/1959 decided on January 16, 1961

precedents_cited.case_name: State of U.P. v. Ibrar Hussain
precedents_cited.citation: Cr. As. 148/1957 and 4 of 1958 decided on April 28, 1959
precedents_cited.relevance: SC observed unnecessary remarks by HC.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Inherent powers to expunge; State rights to appeal, sanction.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate and special leave; executive power in Governor.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, held State had locus standi, High Court has inherent power to expunge in exceptional cases, and directed expungement of the specific sweeping remarks against the police force as unwarranted and unnecessary.

key_quotes.text: "There is not a single lawless group in the whole of the country, whose record of crime comes anywhere near the record of that organised unit which is known as the Indian Police Force."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Sweeping remark by Mulla J. held unwarranted and ordered expunged.

key_quotes.text: "If the Police Force must be manned by officers like Mohammad Naim then it is better that we tear up our Constitution, forget all about democracy and the rights of citizens..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Example of observations criticized for lack of judicial restraint.

key_quotes.text: "...in expressing their opinions judges and Magistrates must be guided by considerations of justice, fairplay and restraint."
key_quotes.speaker: court
